title: Review CLI packaging vs plugins for skills
description:
Current approach: SKILL.md documents relative paths (e.g., python3 sessions.py), Claude constructs full paths at runtime. This results in long bash commands with full paths.

Observations:
- Many skills package python scripts as CLI tools with short readable names
- Some skill repos suggest installing skills as plugins
- Unknown if plugins enable CLI tool installation or have other advantages

Preferences: Keep things simple and low-tech. Only adopt plugins if there are real advantages.

Questions to answer:
1. How do other skills package scripts as CLI tools?
2. What do plugins provide beyond simple skill folders?
3. Is there a lightweight way to get short CLI commands without full plugin infrastructure?

content:
Research findings:

1. PLUGINS: Claude Code plugins provide slash commands (/hello), custom agents, hooks, and MCP servers - but NOT system CLI tools. They are distribution/packaging mechanisms, not CLI installers. Overkill for our use case.

2. ANTHROPIC SKILLS: Official skills use relative paths in SKILL.md (e.g., python3 extract_text.py). Claude constructs full paths at runtime using base directory context. Same pattern we use.

3. PIP INSTALLABLE: Python's pyproject.toml with console_scripts entry points creates real CLI commands (e.g., 'issues' instead of 'python3 path/to/issues.py'). Requires pip install step but is standard Python packaging.

4. LIGHTWEIGHT ALTERNATIVES:
   - Shell aliases: User adds 'alias issues=python3 /path/to/issues.py' to shell config. Per-user setup.
   - Symlinks: Create symlinks in a PATH directory pointing to scripts
   - Wrapper scripts: Short shell scripts that call full path

Key insight: The verbose bash commands are only visible in Claude's tool calls, not typically shown to users. Token savings from shorter commands is minimal (~10-20 tokens per invocation).

reason: Keeping current approach (full paths). Research found: (1) Plugins don't provide CLI tools - they're distribution mechanisms for slash commands/agents/hooks. (2) Aliases and env vars don't persist across Claude Code bash calls - each invocation is isolated. (3) No viable middle ground exists. The full-path approach is actually the most token-efficient given Claude Code's architecture.
Done - repo published to GitHub

title: Issues board TUI loses focus and cannot re-select issues after certain keybindings

content: Root cause analysis: The TUI uses manual selection tracking (current_column/current_index) but doesn't control Textual's focus system. ScrollableContainer widgets (line 79) are focusable by default and have built-in scroll bindings that may conflict with j/k keys. Fix options: (1) Set can_focus=False on ScrollableContainers, (2) Make the app manage focus explicitly, or (3) Ensure app-level bindings have priority.

reason: Fixed by creating NonFocusableScrollableContainer subclass with can_focus=False, preventing focus from getting trapped in scroll containers

title: TUI board scroll should follow focused card
description: When navigating up/down in issues board (and likely sessions board), selecting a card that is off-screen doesn't trigger scroll to keep the focused card visible. Expected: viewport should scroll to keep the currently focused card on screen.

reason: Fixed - added scroll_visible() call in _update_selection() at issues/tui.py:361-362. When a card is selected via j/k navigation, it now scrolls into view. Sessions board uses ListView which handles scrolling automatically.
